priorVersion.title: CDISC SDTM Device-In-Use Test Name Terminology

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C106482

self.title: CDISC SDTM Device-In-Use Test Name Terminology

definition: A terminology codelist for the test name of the test or examination used to obtain the measurement or finding of the device in use.
name: Device-In-Use Test Name
preferredTerm: CDISC SDTM Device-In-Use Test Name Terminology

terms.definition: The position and orientation of the image slice relative to the patient-based coordinate system. (NCI)

The adjustment for the effect of tissue thicknesses through which gamma's travel from an activity concentration origin to the scanner's detectors. The count rates of a detector are adjusted to values as if there were no attenuation along the gamma's path. This makes possible accurate quantitation in image analysis. (NCI)

A visual stimulus that uses a checkerboard pattern which reverses every half-second (or other specified frequency). The check size can be changed to allow for testing of specific segments of the visual pathway.
The maximum voltage allowable to pass through an electromagnetic coil. (NCI)
An indication as to whether the image reconstruction took into account the time-activity curve during which the radiolabeled tracer decayed as it spread through the body during the image acquisition.
The time in milliseconds between the application of the excitation pulse and the recording of the peak echo signal. (NCI)
The extent of an area that is visible. (NCI)
In magnetic resonance imaging, the rotation of the average axis of the protons, relative to the main magnetic field direction, induced by radiofrequency signals. (NCI)
The number of dimensions that the acquired image(s) are presented in.
A measurement of the number of data fields, pixels or data points assigned to each linear dimension in a digital image. (NCI)

A classification of the technique used to enhance image contrast based on differences in magnetic resonance tissue properties. This can be achieved by changing the echo time or repetition time after the tissue has returned to its equilibrium state.
A measurement of the distance between slices within an image sequence, calculated by subtracting the nominal slice thickness from the couch increment.
The time between the inversion and excitation pulses in an inversion recovery pulse sequence.
The number of channels, or elements, in the coil component of the device.
The number of planar cross-sections in an imaging sequence; each slice corresponds to a single image.
A serially recurrent arrangement of radiofrequency pulses that are applied to the sample. (NCI)
An indication as to whether the device was set to correct for random noise generated by deflected positrons.
The range between the minimum and maximum cut-off frequencies for a particular receiver, commonly measured in Hertz. (NCI)
A classification of the reconstruction filter used to suppress noise, enhance edges, resolution recovery and smooth an image.
The type of mathematical process used to produce the displayed image from the raw k-space data obtained from the receiver circuitry. (NCI)
The amount of time in milliseconds between successive pulse sequences applied to the same slice.
A measurement of the height of the signal.
A measurement of the number of cycles of a periodic wave or pulse per unit of time.
A measurement of the range of values seen in the time interval between the beginning and end of the pulse wave.
The numeric identifier used to identify an image slice. (NCI)
The dimension between two surfaces of an imaging plane. (NCI)
A form or variant of software; one of a sequence of copies of a software program, each incorporating new modifications. (NCI)
The type of electrode (monopolar or bipolar) used on the subject during electrical stimulation of the body or organ.
The image acquisition settings of an ultrasound-based imaging modality, based on parameters including transducer design, ultrasound frequency, and ultrasound signal processing.
A measurement of the distance between the centers of two adjacent pixels located along the X-axis.
A measurement of the distance between the centers of two adjacent pixels located along the Y-axis.
